title: 109_s1975
content: The Act titled "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2005" aims to prevent deceptive practices in elections. The Act "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2005" prohibits knowingly deceiving others about election details. The Act "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2005" prohibits deceiving others about election details and includes qualifications for voter eligibility. It also allows individuals to take legal action for violations. The Act "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2005" includes amendments to sections 2004 and 594 of the United States Code, addressing intimidation and deceptive acts in elections. The Act "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2005" prohibits knowingly deceiving someone about election details to prevent them from voting in presidential, congressional, or other specified elections. Violators face penalties. Any violation of the Act "Deceptive Practices and Voter Intimidation Prevention Act of 2005" may result in a fine of up to $100,000, imprisonment for up to 1 year, or both. The amendments made by this section will be effective upon the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. REPORTING FALSE ELECTION INFORMATION. Any person can report deceptive acts related to election time, place, manner, and voter eligibility for Federal office to the Assistant Attorney General of the Civil Rights Division. The Assistant Attorney General must investigate and take corrective action within 48 hours if deception is confirmed. The Assistant Attorney General must investigate and take corrective action within 48 hours if deception related to election time, place, manner, and voter eligibility for Federal office is confirmed. If a report is received within 72 hours before the election, immediate investigation and corrective measures must be taken to provide correct information to affected voters. The Attorney General shall establish regulations for these procedures. The Attorney General will promulgate regulations for corrective actions in consultation with various organizations. Additionally, a study on the feasibility of providing corrective measures will be conducted in collaboration with the Federal Communications Commission and the Election Assistance Commission. The Attorney General will submit a report to Congress within 180 days detailing the feasibility of providing corrective information through public broadcasts. Additionally, reports on deceptive allegations after elections will be submitted within 90 days. The report will detail allegations of deceptive practices related to elections, including specific tactics, corrective actions taken, effectiveness of those actions, any legal suits filed, and statistical data. The Attorney General must compile and publicly release a report detailing allegations of deceptive practices related to elections, including the number and types of allegations, affected populations, and investigation status. The report must be made available online and through other appropriate means. The term "Federal office" refers to the offices of the President and Vice President. The term "Federal office" includes the President, Vice President, Members of Congress, and Delegates from territories. The Attorney General is authorized to receive necessary funds for implementing this section.
